abstract: There is still little agreement between lawmakers and bankers on how to limit the risks created by huge financial institutions, but one measure with some backing would be a so-called resolution authority, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column.

lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, chief of JPMorgan Chase, may have strong arguments that banks should be able to grow as big as they want, but there is a swelling chorus of leaders in the United States and abroad who are more concerned about the risk that such huge banks present to the rest of the economy, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

headline.main: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
